thread.title: Greece hopes to reach agreement with creditors by Tuesday
thread.title_full: Greece hopes to reach agreement with creditors by Tuesday

title: Greece hopes to reach agreement with creditors by Tuesday
text:
Tip : Use comma (,) to separate multiple quotes. Learn more... 
Mon, Aug 10, 2015, 10:08 BST - UK Markets close in 6 hrs 22 mins Greece hopes to reach agreement with creditors by Tuesday By Aideen Kennedy | Sharecast – 3 minutes 58 seconds ago Print 
LONDON (ShareCast) - (ShareCast News) - Greece hopes to conclude negotiations with its international lenders by early Tuesday, a Greek official said as talked continues in Athens. "Efforts are being made to conclude the negotiations, the horizon is by Monday night or early Tuesday," a Greek official said. 
"When the new bailout comes to parliament for a vote it will be one bill with two articles - one article will be the loan agreement and the MoU (memorandum of understanding) and the second article will be the prior actions," the official explained. 
Greek finance and economy ministers were in negotiations with the four institutions representing Greece's creditors - the European Central Bank (ECB), the International Monetary Fund (IMF), the European Commission and the European Stability Mechanism (ESM) - on Sunday night to lay out a plan that would make as much as €86bn available to Greece. 
Last week Greek government spokeswoman Olga Gerovasili said the country expected to conclude a bailout deal with its international creditors by 18 August, and ruled out the idea pointed out by Germany's finance ministry, who showed to be in favour of a bridging loan for Greece , to give Athens and its international lenders enough time to negotiate a third bailout. 
Greece is due to make a €3.5bn repayment to the European Central Bank (ECB) on 20 August. 
OANDA 's senior market analyst Craig Erlam said that while the Greeks were always "more positive of reaching a deal than anyone else", if this could be achieved it would "certainly be a first given the many battles and 11th hour deals that have come in the past". 
CMC Markets ' Chief Market Analyst Michael Hewson said growing optimism among EU officials would appear to suggest that Greece had made significant concessions with respect to new austerity measures which could be voted on later this week. 
Nevertheless, Hewson emphasised that "EU creditors would need to find a way to bridge the gap between the IMF and Germany about the thorny subject of debt relief, which could be a much harder nut to crack".
